docs.lead_paragraph: A day after the Supreme Court effectively struck down bans on a medical procedure its opponents call partial-birth abortion, supporters of those bans said they were already planning a new generation of laws intended to withstand further legal challenges. In its 5-to-4 decision on Wednesday, the Supreme Court ruled that to be constitutionally acceptable, state laws that ban the procedure must specify the type of procedure barred. The court also found that the state laws must permit use of that procedure if it is considered necessary to preserve the health of the mother. The laws exist in some 30 states.

headline.main: FOES OF ABORTION START NEW EFFORT AFTER COURT LOSS
headline.kicker: THE SUPREME COURT: THE COURSE AHEAD

docs.abstract: Day after Supreme Court effectively struck down bans on medical procedure its opponents call partial-birth abortion, supporters of those bans say they are already planning new generation of laws intended to withstand further legal challenge; court ruled that state laws must specify type of procedure barred and must permit use of procedures when necessary to health of woman; decision came in Nebraska case, but legal experts say it will likely invalidate similar law around the country; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A day after the Supreme Court effectively struck down bans on a medical procedure its opponents call partial-birth abortion, supporters of those bans said they were already planning a new generation of laws intended to withstand further legal...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors who perform abortions as part of their regular medical practices said yesterday that they were greatly relieved by the decision of the Supreme Court that the government could not prohibit doctors from performing a procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion. They said that laws trying to ban the procedure were so vague that doctors performing almost any abortion could be prosecuted under them. The doctors said that medically, there is no such procedure as a partial-birth abortion, calling the term a political label. The Nebraska law struck down by the court described a partial-birth abortion as one in which part of the fetus was outside the woman's body before the fetus was killed. The doctors said many types of abortion could fit that description.

headline.main: Doctors Express Relief Over Decision; Foes of Abortion Vow to Continue Their Fight

docs.abstract: Doctors who perform abortions as part of their regular medical practices laud Supreme Court decision on 'partial-birth' abortions, saying laws trying to ban procedure are so vague that doctors performing almost any abortion could be prosecuted under them; doctors also say that medically there is no such procedure as 'partial-birth' abortion and term is political label; abortion foes say they will push for more specific laws that would meet Supreme Court's standard (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to spare the lives of newborn babies whose mothers are too desperate to care for them, the New Jersey State Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would allow parents to abandon an infant at a hospital or police station without facing criminal penalties. The so-called Safe Haven Bill, which was passed by the Assembly on Monday, will change the state's legal code, which currently treats the abandonment of any child as a crime punishable by up to 10 years in prison. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to sign the bill into law, said Jayne O'Connor, a spokeswoman for the governor.

headline.main: Senate Backs Bill Allowing Safe Havens For Infants

docs.abstract: New Jersey Senate gives final approval to bill that would allow parents to abandon newborn infants at hospital or police station without facing criminal penalties (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a Supreme Court decision on Wednesday overturning a Nebraska law dealing with abortion. The vote in the case, Stenberg v. Carhart was 5 to 4. With the continuation of a front-page article on Thursday, The Times published excerpts from the majority opinion by Justice Stephen G. Breyer and a dissent by Justice Clarence Thomas. But six other justices -- John Paul Stevens, Sanda Day O'Connor, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, William H. Rehnquist, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy -- also wrote opinions. The excerpts below provide a fuller range of views on the court on this case.

headline.main: Excerpts From Supreme Court Opinions on Nebraska's Abortion Law

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled by a 5-to-4 vote today that the government cannot prohibit doctors from performing a procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion because it may be the most medically appropriate way of terminating some pregnancies. The decision declared unconstitutional the Nebraska law before the court and, in effect, the laws of 30 other states. In addition, the bill to create a federal ban on the procedure, which President Clinton has vetoed twice and which may reach his desk again this year, would also be unconstitutional under the court's analysis: like all the other laws, it does not contain an exception for the health of the pregnant woman.

headline.main: Court Rules That Governments Can't Outlaw Type of Abortion
headline.kicker: THE SUPREME COURT: THE NEBRASKA CASE

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules 5 to 4 that government cannot bar doctors from performing procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion because it may be most medically appropriate way of terminating some late-term pregnancies; overturns Nebraska law and, effectively, laws of 30 other states; decision, with majority opinion by Justice Stephen G Breyer, is analytically broader than many expected, finding fault with both Nebraska law's imprecise language and lack of exception for women's health; vote is unexpectedly close, with Justice Anthony M Kennedy's dissenting opinion major surprise; eight of nine justices write opinions in case; Court, in another abortion decision, votes 6 to 3 to uphold Colorado law aimed at protecting abortion clinic patients and doctors from harassment by protesters; Justice John Paul Stevens writes majority opinion; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled by a 5-to-4 vote today that the government cannot prohibit doctors from performing a procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion because it may be the most medically appropriate way of terminating some pregnancies.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from Supreme Court decision overturning a Nebraska law dealing with abortion. The vote in the case, Stenberg v. Carhart, was 5 to 4. The majority opinion was written by Justice Stephen G. Breyer; Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the dissent. FROM THE DECISION By Justice Breyer We again consider the right to an abortion. We understand the controversial nature of the problem. Millions of Americans believe that life begins at conception and consequently that an abortion is akin to causing the death of an innocent child; they recoil at the thought of a law that would permit it. Other millions fear that a law that forbids abortion would condemn many American women to lives that lack dignity, depriving them of equal liberty and leading those with least resources to undergo illegal abortions with the attendant risks of death and suffering.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ended its 1999-2000 term yesterday with a burst of important rulings that could reverberate into the fall elections. The rulings involved a range of contentious social and political issues -- abortion rights, public aid to parochial schools and the civil rights of gay people. On a positive note, a sharply divided court reaffirmed a woman's right to choose the safest method of abortion throughout pregnancy by striking down Nebraska's ''partial-birth abortion'' law and, by extension, similar laws enacted by 30 other states. In contrast, the day's other 5-to-4 decision, holding that the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to exclude gays, was a disappointing departure from a proud line of high court precedents erasing discrimination in public accommodations.
docs.abstract: Editorial hails Supreme Court decision striking down Nebraska's ban on abortion procedure opponents call partial-birth abortion as reaffirmation of woman's right to choose safest abortion method; cites concern over Justice Anthony Kennedy's dissent; holds ruling vindicates Pres Clinton's repeated veto of Congressional attempts to impose national ban; holds court's decision upholding law that requires public school districts to share equipment in 'secular, neutral and nonideological' way with students enrolled in private schools does not show how court will vote on school vouchers; scores court's decision in favor of Boy Scout's right to exclude gay members
